image.altText: a woman with blonde hair

items.synopsis: Transport Minster Jo Haylen was aware in July of at least two donations made to her campaign from Josh Murray and his wife, but she said they were just tickets to a fundraising event.

title.children: NSW minister says she won't resign over donations made by man she hired for $600k job

image.altText: A woman in a sea of protesters holds a placard that reads "Not all men but too many"

items.synopsis: The women of the World Cup displayed nothing but merit. Extraordinary feats of skill. Flawless sportsmanship. Good behaviour on and off the pitch. They generated millions of new eyeballs for the beautiful game. And yet, they were overshadowed again and again by second-rate blokes, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: It's a classic tale of meritorious women overshadowed by second-rate blokes

image.altText: A composite image of the leaders of the Labor, Liberal and Greens parties.

items.synopsis: The independent tribunal that sets politician pay has determined to give federal MPs a 4 per cent pay rise, saying previous pay increases have been conservative.

title.children: PM's pay bumped to $586k, Dutton's to $417k as salary increases for federal politicians rolled out

image.altText: Linda Burney, standing in front of a group of people, holds a press conference outside with gum trees behind her

items.synopsis: Australia's most senior Indigenous politician has broken her silence about her speech, having faced a campaign of whispers about her health.

title.children: 'My voice has changed': Linda Burney breaks silence amid whisper campaign

image.altText: Cooking on a gas stove

items.synopsis: Experts say getting households and businesses that can easily disconnect from gas is key to meeting emission reduction targets.

title.children: New home gas bans will lead to energy source's 'death spiral', experts say

image.altText: Osprey military aircraft taking off from landing helicopter assault vessel.

items.synopsis: The V-22 Osprey has recorded more than 50 fatalities in accidents over the past three decades. On Sunday, the aircraft's death toll grew again.

title.children: Dubbed 'the Widowmaker' after a series of deadly accidents, why is the Osprey still in use?

image.altText: Woman takes selfie and smiles at camera

items.synopsis: From making space for more complainants to report, to supporting them from start to finish, here's what experts say the justice systems needs to do to better support victim-survivors of sexual assault.

title.children: Karen was palmed off after being sexually assaulted while on holiday. She says the system could change today

image.altText: A toddler in a blue onesie ith ears, wears socks, sits on an unmade bed with a velvet brown bedhead.

items.synopsis: Twenty-one-month-old Jordan Thompson died in a unit in a Singleton apartment block in March 2005. His mother's ex-boyfriend has pleaded not guilty to manslaughter.

title.children: Accused toddler killer talked about crushing up sedatives to make kids sleep, jury hears

image.altText: Margot winks at the camera as she claps in the air while wearing a gold glittery jumpsuit.

items.synopsis: Come on Barbie, lets go break some box office records in the US and internationally.

title.children: Barbie topples Harry Potter to become Warner Bros' highest-grossing film of all time

image.altText: A composite image shows the three marines in side-by-side images

items.synopsis: The pilot, crew chief and squadron executive officer have been identified as the three US marines killed in Sunday's Osprey crash on Melville Island in the Northern Territory.

title.children: US marines killed in Osprey crash on Tiwi Islands identified

image.altText: Woman holding baby with head turned away

items.synopsis: Essie Mitchell first spoke to her GP about a lump in her breast when she was 22. But it took 11 years and three more visits before her cancer was finally picked up, by which time it was too late to operate.

title.children: Mum's devastating diagnosis comes too late despite years of tests

image.altText: image of woman in yellow work gear in front of sign with a picture of a wombat and slow down warning

items.synopsis: It's earmarked for nearly 30,000 new homes, but urbanisation and feral deer in Sydney's Wollondilly shire are muscling wombats and koalas onto busy arterial roads with "overwhelming" vehicle strikes, wildlife rescuers say.

title.children: Wombat, koala roadkill doubles in one of Sydney's main growth areas

image.altText: Woman in red lipstick smiling

items.synopsis: A new report by the NSW Productivity Commission found infrastructure to support new homes is cheapest when built near Sydney's CBD.

title.children: Mosman mayor fights 'unreasonable' government suggestion for more houses in her area

image.altText: A worm in a specimen pot

items.synopsis: In a world first, doctors have extracted a living roundworm usually found in carpet pythons, from a patient's brain. They believe the infection occurred after the patient ate contaminated native greens.

title.children: 'I realised it was moving': Roundworm pulled from patient's brain likely came from carpet python

image.altText: picture of a man holding a metal bucket sitting in a football stadium behind the goal post

items.synopsis: Alex Agelopoulos, who injured a goalkeeper with a bucket when Melbourne Victory fans violently stormed AAMI Park, was released on bail after his lawyer immediately appealed the three-month jail term he was handed.

title.children: 'Bucket man' handed jail sentence over violent pitch invasion at Melbourne A-League game

image.altText: A split image of two female NRL officials, both watching looking across field at rugby league games.

items.synopsis: Belinda Sharpe and Kasey Badger are appointed to referee NRL matches this weekend, making them the first women to do so under the one-referee system.

title.children: Belinda Sharpe and Kasey Badger become NRL's first solo female referees

image.altText: A woman holding a TEMU bag

items.synopsis: A flashy new online shopping app has been bombarding Australians on social media. While some see it as the saviour of China's economy, not everyone is convinced.

title.children: Are you getting a lot of ads for TEMU? The Chinese retailer is coming for Amazon – and it might win

image.altText: A large set of drones is pictured inside a big warehouse-like space.

items.synopsis: There are five key observations which can be made about drones from their use in the war in Ukraine. And the Australian Defence Force needs to take notice, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: A 44-day conflict was a sign of what was to come in Ukraine. Now we know drones are changing warfare

image.altText: Tails of Qantas and Virgin Australia aircraft

items.synopsis: Local stocks rise in early trade and the bosses of Virgin and Qantas are at loggerheads on a decision to block extra flights by Qatar Airways. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX makes gains, Virgin calls for rethink on extra Qatar flights

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) says steel manufacturer BlueScope Steel has been ordered to pay a $57.5 million penalty for attempting to fix prices for flat steel products supplied in Australia. The penalty ordered by the Federal Court today is the highest penalty ever imposed for cartel conduct in Australia. The Court also imposed a $575,000 penalty on BlueScope’s former general manager, Jason Ellis, which by Court order cannot be recovered from an insurance company. From the ACCC's press release: Justice O’Bryan said that “the conduct in the present case warrants a significant penalty to deter repetition by Mr Ellis and by others who may otherwise calculate that the rewards from such conduct outweigh the risks of detection. It is important that the deterrent effect of the penalty being imposed is not undermined by the ability of company directors and officers to insure against the financial cost of the penalty.” In December 2022 the Court found that BlueScope and Mr Ellis had attempted to induce eight steel distributors in Australia, and an overseas manufacturer, Yieh Phui, to enter agreements to fix and/or raise the level of pricing for flat steel products. “This should serve as a strong warning to all businesses and individuals that attempting to fix prices with competitors will have very serious consequences, even if the attempt fails and they do not reach an agreement,” ACCC Commissioner Liza Carver said. “We welcome this substantial penalty against BlueScope. It is important that penalties are sufficiently large to deter even large companies and their employees from breaching Australia’s competition laws.” “Cartel conduct is illegal because it cheats Australians by increasing the prices consumers and business customers have to pay, and by restricting healthy economic growth,” Ms Carver said. “If BlueScope had been successful in reaching an agreement to fix prices with its competitors, this would have reduced price competition and increased prices for flat steel products which are widely used in the construction, manufacturing, automotive and transport industries.” Justice O’Bryan found that the conduct by BlueScope was deliberate and systematic and considered that “only a substantial penalty for each of the attempts to induce cartel conduct will serve the objectives of specific and general deterrence”. He found that the conduct by BlueScope was of a serious kind, was carried out at a senior level of the company, had the potential to occasion significant loss and damage and to deliver substantial financial gain to BlueScope. BlueScope and Mr Ellis were also ordered to pay the ACCC’s costs.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Record $57.5 million penalty for BlueScope’s attempted price fixing

children.content: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) says steel manufacturer BlueScope Steel has been ordered to pay a
$57.5 million penalty for attempting to fix prices
for flat steel products supplied in Australia.
The penalty ordered by the
Federal Court
today is the
highest penalty ever imposed for cartel conduct in Australia.
The Court also imposed a $575,000 penalty on BlueScope’s former general manager, Jason Ellis,
which by Court order cannot be recovered from an insurance company.
From the ACCC's press release:

Justice O’Bryan said that “the conduct in the present case warrants a significant penalty to deter repetition by Mr Ellis and by others who may otherwise calculate that the rewards from such conduct outweigh the risks of detection. It is important that the deterrent effect of the penalty being imposed is not undermined by the ability of company directors and officers to insure against the financial cost of the penalty.”
In December 2022 the Court found
that BlueScope and Mr Ellis
had attempted to induce eight steel distributors in Australia
, and an
overseas manufacturer, Yieh Phui
, to enter agreements to fix and/or raise the level of pricing for flat steel products.

“This should serve as a strong warning to all businesses and individuals that attempting to fix prices with competitors will have very serious consequences, even if the attempt fails and they do not reach an agreement,”
ACCC Commissioner Liza Carver
said.

“We welcome this substantial penalty against BlueScope. It is important that penalties are sufficiently large to deter even large companies and their employees from breaching Australia’s competition laws.”
“Cartel conduct is illegal because it cheats Australians by increasing the prices consumers and business customers have to pay, and by restricting healthy economic growth,” Ms Carver said.

“If BlueScope had been successful in reaching an agreement to fix prices with its competitors, this would have reduced price competition and increased prices for flat steel products which are widely used in the construction, manufacturing, automotive and transport industries.”
Justice O’Bryan found that the conduct by BlueScope was deliberate and systematic
and considered that “only a substantial penalty for each of the attempts to induce cartel conduct will serve the objectives of specific and general deterrence”.
He found that
the conduct by BlueScope
was of a serious kind,
was carried out at a senior level of the company
, had the potential to occasion significant loss and damage and to deliver substantial financial gain to BlueScope.
BlueScope and Mr Ellis were also ordered to pay the ACCC’s costs.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government needs to come clean and confirm who was responsible for the final decision to reject Qatar Airways' bid for an additional 21 weekly flights in Australia, says Flight Centre CEO Graham Turner. The fallout from the rejection has been simmering for days, and Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones telling the AFR that the rejection was in the national interest and would keep Qantas profitable on Monday only reignited the debate. Speaking to the ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan, Mr Turner said the federal government needs to be up front about who ultimately signed off on vetoing Qatar's bid. "I believe the recommendation from the Department of Transport to the minister, Catherine King, was that it be allowed," he told The World Today. "But the story is that it was someone above her that basically had a captain's call, presumably the Prime Minister. "So it'd be interesting to know: who actually made the call, who made the decision, what the recommendation was, and what was the reason for it? "Because these are questions that [have] just not been answered yet." He said people deserve an explanation to understand what was behind the government's decision making process as they face expensive airfares when booking flights. "A lot of people, a lot of industries, you know, relatively small industries in tourism and travel have been negatively affected by this, [they're seeing] nothing of the relatively expensive airfares that we still have, because there's not enough capacity for the demand at the moment. So airfares are going to stay up ," he said. Mr Turner also believes the issue could end up "blowing up on the government". "I think it could, if they can't give, what their rationale was, what the reason was, who made the decision and why," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Flight Centre CEO says government needs to come clean about Qatar Airways decision

(Supplied: Thomas Pawson)
He said people deserve an explanation to understand what was behind the government's decision making process as they face expensive airfares when booking flights.
"A lot of people, a lot of industries, you know, relatively small
industries in tourism and travel have been negatively affected by this
, [they're seeing] nothing of the relatively expensive airfares that we still have, because there's not enough capacity for the demand at the moment. So
airfares are going to stay up
," he said.
Mr Turner also believes the issue could end up "blowing up on the government".
"I think it could, if they can't give, what their rationale was, what the reason was, who made the decision and why," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Flight Centre boss Graham Turner has described the decision by the federal government to veto the bid by Qatar Airways to double its flights into Australia as one that that has "no logic" behind it. In July it was revealed that Transport Minister Catherine King had rejected Qatar's application for 21 additional flights into Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane per week, on top of its existing 28 weekly flights into Australia's major airports. Yesterday, the Australian Financial Review published comments from Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones, who explained the government's decision to block the extra Qatar flights was in the national interest and would help keep Qantas profitable. During a Senate committee hearing in Melbourne yesterday, Qantas boss Alan Joyce denied twisting the government's arm on rejecting Qatar's proposal, but Mr Turner told The World Today the reasoning doesn't stack up, because there is a need for flight capacity to increase. "There's no logic to it, and it is a bit of a worry because we have more demand than capacity ," he told the ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan. "So any extra capacity that certainly for our industry is very important. "It was clearly not in the national interest as far as I can see. "You could argue that it could have been in Qantas's interests, it certainly wasn't in Virgin's interest because they have a codeshare relationship with Qatar, so I just don't think it was an argument that held any water ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'No logic' to rejecting Qatar Airways' flight bid, says Flight Centre boss

(ABC News: Tom Lowrey)

image.altText: Shane Drumgold out the front of the ACT courts.

items.synopsis: The ACT's outgoing Director of Public Prosecutions, Shane Drumgold, commences legal proceedings against the inquiry into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution, the ACT government and ACT Attorney-General Shane Rattenbury.

title.children: Top prosecutor launches legal proceedings against ACT government, the inquiry into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution

image.altText: Jana Pittman on Q+A

items.synopsis: As politicians are forced to hear their bickering on the Voice is confusing, the Q+A panel agrees that there should be extra funds allocated for paid parental leave.

title.children: Jana Pittman labels Voice messaging 'confusing' on Q+A

image.altText: Artist Tank, wearing a black hoodie and dark beanie, stands in front of a wall mural.

items.synopsis: Tank, who recently spoke out about his designs being sold by the Chinese online retail giant, says Australians have "good standards" and "don't want to see anyone be ripped off for a fair day's work".

title.children: Artist known as Tank wins battle with Temu to get copycat art removed from sale

image.altText: The back of a woman's head to protect her privacy.

items.synopsis: A former Newcastle state ward says an "examination" forced on her in the 1960s amounted to state-sanctioned rape but the National Redress Scheme disagrees.

title.children: Former state ward denied redress over 'virginity test'

image.altText: Two Australian batters and the team captain high-five at the end of a T20 match at the Commonwealth Games.

items.synopsis: A senate inquiry examining why Victoria walked away from hosting the 2026 Commonwealth Games is holding hearings in the regional city of Bendigo. Follow live.

title.children: Australian marathon legend tells inquiry 'terrific history' of Commonwealth Games should continue

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mr Taylor says City of Ballarat CEO Evan King was heavily pressured into signing a non-disclosure agreement in relation to the Commonwealth Games. "All CEO's were — I wouldn't say encouraged, they were more forced — if you wanted to be a part of the conversation, you had to sign those agreements," he says. "We quizzed the CEO multiple times and he had to be very careful of what he even explained to councillors around the process." There are audible outbursts from the Senators after hearing this last quote. "That is an extraordinary revelation, Councillor Taylor," Senator Henderson says. Mr King declined to appear before the public hearing today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: City of Ballarat CEO 'forced' into confidentiality agreement

children.content: Mr Taylor says City of Ballarat CEO Evan King was heavily pressured into signing a non-disclosure agreement in relation to the Commonwealth Games.
"All CEO's were — I wouldn't say encouraged, they were more forced — if you wanted to be a part of the conversation, you had to sign those agreements," he says.
"We quizzed the CEO multiple times and he had to be very careful of what he even explained to councillors around the process."
There are audible outbursts from the Senators after hearing this last quote.
"That is an extraordinary revelation, Councillor Taylor," Senator Henderson says.
Mr King declined to appear before the public hearing today.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Councillor Ben Taylor expands on the disappointment brought by the decision to change the athlete's village to temporary housing. "When we all read it in the newspaper, because that's the only way you find out these things from the government, it kind of ripped the heart out of the community," he says. "To realise what we thought we were going to get wasn't going to happen and they'd ship them in on the back of a truck and then drive them out on the back of a truck, not providing that community benefit." Senator Henderson references evidence given by Michael Poulton earlier in the day, where he stated that the thoughts and needs of the Ballarat community felt ignored by the state government. Ms Johnson credits Mr Poulton with his diligent work in preparing for the now cancelled Games, and echoes his sentiments. "In my experience, we certainly didn't have any genuine consultation as to how we thought the infrastructure projects were going to be best delivered," she says. "Right across the board, I feel like we weren't genuinely consulted with."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ballarat housing decision 'ripped the heart out of the community'

children.content: Councillor Ben Taylor expands on the disappointment brought by the decision to change the athlete's village to temporary housing.
"When we all read it in the newspaper, because that's the only way you find out these things from the government, it kind of ripped the heart out of the community," he says.

"To realise what we thought we were going to get wasn't going to happen and they'd ship them in on the back of a truck and then drive them out on the back of a truck, not providing that community benefit."
Senator Henderson references evidence given by Michael Poulton earlier in the day, where he stated that the thoughts and needs of the Ballarat community felt ignored by the state government.
Ms Johnson credits Mr Poulton with his diligent work in preparing for the now cancelled Games, and echoes his sentiments.
"In my experience, we certainly didn't have any genuine consultation as to how we thought the infrastructure projects were going to be best delivered," she says.
"Right across the board, I feel like we weren't genuinely consulted with."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ballarat Deputy Mayor Amy Johnson and councillor Ben Taylor are now calling into the hearing. Ballarat was due to host a range of events in the 2026 Games including athletics, boxing and the marathon. Ms Johnson says the state government committed to the Games with the expectation that council "drop everything" to ensure they were prepared for the games. She says there was no agreement or discussion with the city before the government went ahead with the commitment to host. "I find it incredibly frustrating that that expectation was there, that we re-allocate our resources and the attention of our council and our finite organisational resources for preparing for the Games," Ms Johnson says. "We were never party to the discussions prior to the Games and yet it was essentially demanded that our attention be taken away from business as usual and that it be diverted to be hosting around 4,500 athletes and hundreds of thousands of visitors." Ms Johnson says councillors consistently raised concerns about this, and says many projects have been delayed as a result of the focus on the Games.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Representatives from Ballarat City Council next

children.content: Ballarat Deputy Mayor Amy Johnson and councillor Ben Taylor are now calling into the hearing.
Ballarat was due to host a range of events in the 2026 Games including athletics, boxing and the marathon.
Ms Johnson says the state government committed to the Games with the expectation that council "drop everything" to ensure they were prepared for the games.
She says there was no agreement or discussion with the city before the government went ahead with the commitment to host.

"I find it incredibly frustrating that that expectation was there, that we re-allocate our resources and the attention of our council and our finite organisational resources for preparing for the Games," Ms Johnson says.

"We were never party to the discussions prior to the Games and yet it was essentially demanded that our attention be taken away from business as usual and that it be diverted to be hosting around 4,500 athletes and hundreds of thousands of visitors."
Ms Johnson says councillors consistently raised concerns about this, and says many projects have been delayed as a result of the focus on the Games.

items.synopsis: Many of us are now dressed head to toe in plastic thanks to the invention of cheap and durable textiles like polyester. But the extent of the environmental impact from these garments might surprise you — we've tracked the life cycle of a polyester top from an oil field, through to when you chuck it in the bin.

title.children: In Australia, 6,000kg of clothing is dumped in landfill every 10 minutes. This is the life cycle of a polyester T-shirt

image.altText: A tabby cat lies sleeping on a bookshelf with its head resting on a book.

items.synopsis: The RSPCA appeals for information over the "wicked, cowardly and callous" drowning of a beloved pet cat in the Swan River in Perth's east. WARNING: This article contains details that some readers may find distressing.

title.children: Tiger Tim's owners spent two weeks desperately searching for him, but he had been deliberately drowned in a river

image.altText: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen stands behind a lecturn cpvered in flowers. Two microphones are pointed at her.

items.synopsis: Taipei says it's hopeful to strengthen trade and bilateral relations despite Canberra's attempts to stabilise ties with Beijing.

title.children: Taiwan wants Australia's backing to join trade pact as Beijing pushes for it to be blocked

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

title.children: Besieged Spanish soccer boss asked to quit amid sex assault probe and mother's hunger strike

image.altText: A male tennis player wearing red, white and dark blue shirt and shorts, hits a forehand.

items.synopsis: One of the biggest wins of Rinky Hijikata's career leaves him feeling conflicted after a shooting at his old school in North Carolina.

title.children: Aussie wildcard rocked by shooting at his former US college

image.altText: Four men hold a giant dead alligator with its mouth open

items.synopsis: Four hunters in Mississippi have detailed their "mentally exhausting" seven-hour ordeal after they caught an alligator measuring more than four metres long.

title.children: Seven hour fight to nab 364kg record-breaking alligator in Mississippi river
